articles.headline: Bribery Case at Wal-Mart May Widen
articles.snippet: The scope of an investigation into foreign bribery issues seemed to have widened at the retailer, which reported higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings.
articles.abstract: The scope of an investigation into foreign bribery issues seemed to have widened at the retailer, which reported higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Wal-Mart reported higher-than-expected first-quarter earnings on Thursday, it suggested in a regulatory filing that the scope of an internal investigation into bribery accusations had widened beyond the retailer’s subsidiary in Mexico.

articles.headline: Lessons From Trades Big and Bad
articles.snippet: A multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan may remind some of the disaster at the Long Term Capital Management hedge fund in 1998.
articles.abstract: A multibillion-dollar trading loss at JPMorgan may remind some of the disaster at the Long Term Capital Management hedge fund in 1998.

articles.headline: U.S. Slaps High Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
articles.snippet: The United States Commerce Department concluded that Chinese producers had “dumped” their products on the American market.
articles.abstract: The United States Commerce Department concluded that Chinese producers had “dumped” their products on the American market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States on Thursday announced the imposition of antidumping tariffs of more than 31 percent on solar panels from China.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Diane Cardwell

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard to Cut 30,000 Jobs
articles.snippet: The tech giant will refocus on product development and sales, executives say, and operations in China will most likely be spared.
articles.abstract: The tech giant will refocus on product development and sales, executives say, and operations in China will most likely be spared.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, Meg Whitman, plans to cut 30,000 or more jobs next week, according to officials familiar with the plan. Her goal, they said Thursday, is to spend the money she saves on increasing the efficiency of the company’s sales force and on creating new products.

articles.headline: Cataloging Wounds of War to Help Heal Them
articles.snippet: Col. Michael D. Wirt’s database of injuries and treatment in his corner of the Afghan war could be a model for improving care, but the military has yet to follow his example.
articles.abstract: Col. Michael D. Wirt’s database of injuries and treatment in his corner of the Afghan war could be a model for improving care, but the military has yet to follow his example.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. — To those unfamiliar with a battlefield’s bleak routine, Col. Michael D. Wirt’s database could be read like a catalog of horrors. In it, more than 500 American soldiers are subjected to characteristic forms of violence of the Afghan war.

articles.headline: A Greek Exit? Euro Zone May Be Ready
articles.snippet: Years of foot-dragging and brinkmanship have prepared the currency union for life without Greece.
articles.abstract: Years of foot-dragging and brinkmanship have prepared the currency union for life without Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is increasingly conceivable that Greece may leave the euro zone, not just because of its own political dysfunction but also because the consequences of such an exit for the rest of the Europe and the global economy no longer seem quite so scary.

articles.headline: ‘Princelings’ in China Use Family Ties to Gain Riches
articles.snippet: The authorities are eager to paint the fallen official Bo Xilai, whose family has a substantial fortune, as a rogue operator. But other officials’ relatives have also amassed vast wealth.
articles.abstract: The authorities are eager to paint the fallen official Bo Xilai, whose family has a substantial fortune, as a rogue operator. But other officials’ relatives have also amassed vast wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The Hollywood studio DreamWorks Animation recently announced a bold move to crack China’s tightly protected film industry: a $330 million deal to create a Shanghai animation studio that might one day rival the California shops that turn out hits like “Kung Fu Panda” and “The Incredibles.”
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Preferred Style: Don’t Flaunt It in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: At Facebook, ground zero for the nouveau tech riche in Silicon Valley, peer pressure dictates that consumption be kept on the down low.
articles.abstract: At Facebook, ground zero for the nouveau tech riche in Silicon Valley, peer pressure dictates that consumption be kept on the down low.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Wealth is here if you know where to find it.

articles.headline: Magnate Steps Into 2012 Fray on Wild Pitch
articles.snippet: Word that Joe Ricketts had considered bankrolling advertisements invoking the incendiary race-infused statements of President Obama’s former pastor drew wide denunciation.
articles.abstract: Word that Joe Ricketts had considered bankrolling advertisements invoking the incendiary race-infused statements of President Obama’s former pastor drew wide denunciation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joe Ricketts, an up-by-the-bootstraps billionaire whose varied holdings include a name-brand brokerage firm in Omaha, a baseball team in Chicago, herds of bison in Wyoming and a start-up news Web site in New York, wanted to be a player in the 2012 election. On Thursday he was, though not in the way he had intended.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Markets End Week With a Losing Streak Intact
articles.snippet: Excitement about Facebook did not keep the major indexes from losing ground for the third week in a row.
articles.abstract: Excitement about Facebook did not keep the major indexes from losing ground for the third week in a row.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors drove American stock indexes to their worst weekly performance of the year after excitement about Facebook’s stock offering failed to chase away the pessimism that has increasingly gripped investors in recent weeks.

articles.headline: In the Undoing of a C.E.O., a Puzzle
articles.snippet: A faked résumé led to a victory for an activist shareholder, and an enduring mystery about Scott Thompson’s departure from Yahoo.
articles.abstract: A faked résumé led to a victory for an activist shareholder, and an enduring mystery about Scott Thompson’s departure from Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the activist shareholder Daniel Loeb confronted Yahoo’s directors on May 3 with the possibility that Yahoo’s recently hired chief executive, Scott Thompson, might have falsified his résumé by claiming to have a computer science degree, their initial reaction was disbelief. “Scott is a forthright, no-nonsense, straightforward personality and a likable guy,” one director said.
